newsitem.title: UK: Lassa fever threatens Sierra Leone capital - doctors.
newsitem.headline: Lassa fever threatens Sierra Leone capital - doctors.

text.p: The worst-ever outbreak of lassa fever, a deadly haemorrhagic disease similar to ebola, is threatening to spread to Sierra Leone's capital Freetown, British aid doctors said on Thursday.
Britain's Medical Emergency Relief International (Merlin) said case numbers in the epidemic had doubled since December.
Refugees fleeing civil war were packing into the town of Kenema and conditions were just right for the spread of the highly virulent disease, the organisation said in a statement.
"This is the worst outbreak of lassa fever since records began," said Richard Allen, medical adviser to Merlin.
"Now we are concerned that lassa fever may spread from the bush to the capital city, Freetown. The first suspected case of lassa fever was admitted to a Freetown hospital this week."
The volunteer medical group said it had flown a lassa specialist nurse, drugs and equipment to Freetown.
Spokesman Jonathan Lorie said there had been 239 cases with 35 deaths so far this year -- compared to 367 cases and 93 deaths for the whole of last year.
"It happens every spring," he said. "There was an epidemic last summer but it died down in the autumn and the whole thing has built up afresh since January."
The virus is transmitted through rat's urine or bodily fluids -- including sweat. "You can get it just by shaking hands, if someone infected is sweaty and you have a cut on your hand," Lorie said.

Last year's outbreak had an unprecedented 60 percent mortality rate -- lassa usually kills about 15 percent of its victims. Lorie said the same vicious strain was probably involved this year but having drugs on hand helped survival.
But he added: "Finding the drugs is a real problem because there are only two sources in the world for it."
Only one drug -- Ribavirin -- can cure lassa. Lorie said Merlin was buying the drug through a wholesaler at a discounted price of five pounds (eight dollars) a dose.
The disease takes its name from Lassa village in northern Nigeria, where it was first recorded in 1969.
Provincial officials fear the Sierra Leone toll could be higher as some afflicted people are in areas cut off by rebels who have been waging a guerrilla campaign since 1991.
